title: How to Remove Leading or Trailing Zeros in Excel

steps.title: Highlight the cells with leading zeros.
steps.content: Highlight the cells with leading zeros. If you’re working with numbers in a column, you can highlight the whole column by clicking the column letter.

steps.title: Right-click the highlighted cells.
steps.content: Right-click the highlighted cells. If your computer doesn’t have a right mouse button, press Ctrl as you click with the left. A menu will appear.

steps.title: Click Format Cells.
steps.content: Click Format Cells . The Format Cells dialog will appear.

steps.title: Select Number from the left column.
steps.content: Select Number from the left column.

steps.title: Type a “0” (zero) into the “Decimal Places” box.
steps.content: Type a “0” (zero) into the “Decimal Places” box.

steps.title: Click OK.
steps.content: Click OK . It’s at the bottom-right corner of the screen. This brings you back to your spreadsheet, where you should no longer see zeros before your numbers. If you still see leading zeros, double-click the cells, then press ↵ Enter or ⏎ Return .

steps.title: Highlight the cells with trailing zeros.
steps.content: Highlight the cells with trailing zeros. If you’re working with numbers in a column, you can highlight the whole column by clicking the column letter.

steps.title: Right-click the highlighted cells.
steps.content: Right-click the highlighted cells. If your computer doesn’t have a right mouse button, press Ctrl as you click with the left. A menu will appear.

steps.title: Click Format Cells.
steps.content: Click Format Cells . The Format Cells dialog will appear.

steps.title: Select Custom from the left column.
steps.content: Select Custom from the left column.

steps.title: Type a code into the box under “Type.”
steps.content: Type a code into the box under “Type.” If any text is in the box, delete it now. Then, type 0.### into the box.

steps.title: Click OK.
steps.content: Click OK . You will no longer see extraneous zeros at the ends of your numbers.
